For any real number T > 0 and any function f from the additive circle of T to a normed additive commutative group with a real normed space, the integral of f over (t, t + T] equals the integral of its restriction to the additive circle of T.

This theorem states that for any type `X` equipped with a topological space structure, a set `s` of `X`, and a proposition `p` about elements of `X`, the proposition `p` holds true eventually in the neighborhood filter of the set `s` if and only if there exists a larger open set `t` that contains `s` and the proposition `p` holds true for all elements in `t`. In other words, we can say that a property being true "eventually" in the neighborhood of a set `s` is equivalent to the property being true for all elements of a larger open set that contains `s`. This is a fundamental concept in topology and is used to formalize the notion of continuity and limit.

âˆ€ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] {s : Set X} {p : X â†’ Prop},
  (âˆ€á¶  (x : X) in nhdsSet s, p x) â†” âˆƒ t, IsOpen t âˆ§ s âŠ† t âˆ§ âˆ€ x âˆˆ t, p x
name: eventually_nhdsSet_iff_exists
docString: This theorem states that for any type `X` equipped with a topological space structure, a set `s` of `X`, and a proposition `p` about elements of `X`, the proposition `p` holds true eventually in the neighborhood filter of the set `s` if and only if there exists a larger open set `t` that contains `s` and the proposition `p` holds true for all elements in `t`. In other words, we can say that a property being true "eventually" in the neighborhood of a set `s` is equivalent to the property being true for all elements of a larger open set that contains `s`. This is a fundamental concept in topology and is used to formalize the notion of continuity and limit.

If T is a continuous, self-adjoint linear map between two normed, additive commutative groups and inner product spaces E and F, then the composition of T with any continuous linear map S from E to F and the adjoint of S is also a self-adjoint linear map.

name: IsSelfAdjoint.conj_adjoint
docString: If T is a continuous, self-adjoint linear map between two normed, additive commutative groups and inner product spaces E and F, then the composition of T with any continuous linear map S from E to F and the adjoint of S is also a self-adjoint linear map.

This theorem states that if a function `f` from the reals to a normed additively commutative group `E` is periodic with a positive period `T`, then the integral of `f` over any interval of length `T` is the same, regardless of where that interval starts. More formally, for any real numbers `t` and `s`, the integral of `f` from `t` to `t + T` is equal to the integral of `f` from `s` to `s + T`.

name: Function.Periodic.intervalIntegral_add_eq_of_pos
docString: This theorem states that if a function `f` from the reals to a normed additively commutative group `E` is periodic with a positive period `T`, then the integral of `f` over any interval of length `T` is the same, regardless of where that interval starts. More formally, for any real numbers `t` and `s`, the integral of `f` from `t` to `t + T` is equal to the integral of `f` from `s` to `s + T`.
